dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, we've got to talk about this ongoing, uh, saga, right? Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey. It feels like they're constantly, like, squaring off now.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The afternoon jousting added to a growing public spat between the two Internet moguls, both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And this latest round? It's all about free speech, political advertising, and, you know, who's got the moral high ground on these platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And this latest round? It's all about free speech, political advertising, and, you know, who's got the moral high ground on these platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now the two billionaire tech founders are at odds over how to handle free speech and political advertising, defending opposite views of a heavily debated internet issue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And it really kicked off with Twitter's big announcement, didn't it? Just this past Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And it really kicked off with Twitter's big announcement, didn't it? Just this past Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! They just came right out and said, "No more political ads on our platform." Like, full stop. Their reasoning was, uh, "political message reach should be earned, not bought." Which, I mean, is a pretty strong statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! They just came right out and said, No more political ads on our platform. Like, full stop. Their reasoning was, uh, political message reach should be earned, not bought. Which, I mean, is a pretty strong statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the timing, Host_B, was *chefs kiss*. It was right before Facebook's earnings call, and after Zuckerberg had been, like, campaigning for his own stance on political ads and free speech for a whole month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the timing, Host B, was chefs kiss. It was right before Facebook's earnings call, and after Zuckerberg had been, like, campaigning for his own stance on political ads and free speech for a whole month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The announcement from Dorseys Twitter account came on the cusp of Facebooks scheduled third-quarter earnings call and after a month of relentless campaigning from Zuckerberg on the issue of political advertising and free speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Dorsey didn't pull any punches, saying, "This isn't about free expression. This is about paying for reach." He really emphasized the "paying" part, adding that, you know, our democratic infrastructure might not be ready for the ramifications of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Dorsey didn't pull any punches, saying, This isn't about free expression. This is about paying for reach. He really emphasized the paying part, adding that, you know, our democratic infrastructure might not be ready for the ramifications of that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt about free expression, Dorsey said in a series of tweets. This is about paying for reach. And paying to increase the reach of political speech has significant ramifications that todays democratic infrastructure may not be prepared to handle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, uh, I think is a really salient point. It's not just about saying what you want; it's about amplifying it to millions of people because you, like, paid for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, I think is a really salient point. It's not just about saying what you want; it's about amplifying it to millions of people because you, like, paid for it.

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And he took a pretty veiled shot, or maybe not so veiled, at Zuckerberg, actually. And then he added a wink emoji.

Then, he added a wink.
